content.title: Essential Hydration for Uromastyx
content.content: Uromastyx are desert specialists that get much of their water from food, but they still benefit from access to clean drinking water. Hydration should be provided without raising overall humidity.
In arid habitats, Uromastyx use plant moisture, occasional surface water, and humid burrows to stay hydrated. Captive setups should mirror this balance.

content.text: Natural Water Sources:

content.content: Key insight: Uromastyx need hydration without high ambient humidity. Aim for dry air with localized moisture in burrows.
Use a small water dish, hydrating foods, and a slightly damp lower substrate layer.

content.text: Hydration Method Comparison:

content.content: Avoid heavy misting or foggers. High ambient humidity can cause respiratory issues in Uromastyx.

content.text: Water Dish Specifications:
Water Quality Maintenance:

rows: Rinse dish and refill with dechlorinated water

content.content: Use dechlorinated tap water. Avoid distilled water as a sole source because it lacks minerals.
Maintain a slightly damp lower layer of substrate on the cool side. The surface should stay dry.
Routine soaking is not needed. Only soak under veterinary guidance or for stubborn shed.
Never leave a Uromastyx unattended in water. Use shallow water and short durations if a soak is recommended.

rows: Verify temps and seek vet advice

content.content: Most hydration problems trace back to low basking temperatures or a dry, low-variety diet. Verify heat and diet first.
